logo: Argus Research Visible Text and Design : • The logo consists of a stylized white archway or capital "A" within a blue circle, with a small globe at the base of the arch. • To the right, the text "ARGUS" appears in large, uppercase serif font, with a registered trademark symbol (®) at the upper right of the "S". • Below "ARGUS", the word "RESEARCH" appears in smaller, spaced-out uppercase letters. • The background is solid blue, and all text and the archway are white. Dimensions and Placement : • The archway symbol is positioned to the left of the text. • The logo is horizontally oriented, with the icon and text aligned on a single line. Analysis : • The use of a globe and archway suggests a global or comprehensive perspective, fitting for a research or analytics firm. • The blue and white color scheme conveys professionalism and trust. ADVANCED MICRO DEVICES (NAS:AMD) Report Date: July 09, 2025 Summary : This figure shows a time series line chart of a variable fluctuating between approximately $55 and $214, spanning from early 2023 to mid-2025. line chart: Title & Axes : • No explicit title visible. • X-axis: Date, labeled with major ticks at Jan 1 and Jul 1 for years 2023, 2024, and 2025. • Y-axis: Value in dollars ($), with tick labels at $55, $87, $119, $150, $182, and $214. Data Points : • Single series plotted as a continuous blue line. • Data points are not individually marked; the line is smooth and continuous. • The series starts near $70 in early 2023, dips below $60, rises steadily through 2023, peaks above $200 in early 2024, then fluctuates and trends downward, with a recovery in mid-2025. Design Encodings : • Blue line, no markers, no gridlines, no error bars or confidence intervals. • No log scale or dual axes. Distribution & Trends : • Initial decline from early 2023 to mid-2023. • Gradual increase from mid-2023, accelerating into early 2024. • Sharp peak above $200 in early 2024. • Volatile fluctuations through 2024, with several local peaks and troughs. • Downward trend into early 2025, followed by a recovery toward mid-2025. Analysis : • The data shows a pronounced rise from mid-2023 to early 2024, reaching a maximum above $200. • After the peak, the series becomes volatile, with multiple ups and downs. • There is a notable decline in early 2025, but the value recovers by mid-2025. • The overall pattern is cyclical with a major peak in early 2024 and a recovery phase in mid-2025. Over the past year, AMD shares are down 25.1%, versus a gain of 10.5% for the broader market. The 52 week trading range is $76.48 to $187.28. The Argus A6 target price is $145 representing a 5.2% gain from the current level. Advanced Micro Devices designs a variety of digital semiconductors for markets such as PCs, gaming consoles, data centers, industrial, and automotive applications.

Our rating on the Information Technology sector is Over-Weight. Consumer electronics demand, which was reduced by inflation, is now showing signs of recovery. IT demand in enterprise and data center markets weakened after consumer demand but now also shows signs of recovery, fueled by mounting interest in generative AI. As of the end of May, the sector accounted for 31.6% of the S&P 500. Over the past five years, the weighting has ranged from 16% to 33%. The sector was underperforming the market, with a loss of 1.8%. The sector outperformed in 2024, with a gain of 35.7% compared to a gain of 23.3% for the S&P 500. The sector's P/E ratio on projected 2026 EPS was 23, above the market multiple. Yields of 0.2% were below the market average. The sector's smoothed earnings growth rate of 15% was above the market average. Over the long term, we expect the Tech sector to benefit from pervasive digitization across the economy, greater acceptance of transformative technologies, and the development of the Internet of Things (IoT). Generative AI is poised to become a huge industry driver, although timeline of actual AI deployments is uncertain. Healthy company and sector fundamentals are also positive. For individual companies, these include high cash levels, low debt, and broad international business exposure. Key Sector Trends Communications Equipment - Data demand is exploding because of mobile internet, video on the web, social networking and other factors. Generative AI has shifted from an emerging driver to perhaps the most-significant factor in communications equipment demand. AI is driving demand for bandwidth capacity at the optical transport level as well as network efficiency (IP) and ubiquity (Ethernet) at the access level. - Prevailing trends in the global information society - including collaboration, virtualization, cloud, social networking, and exponential growth in "big" file-based data - are driving the need for more network "intelligence," meaning security, efficiency, extensibility, personalization, and sophisticated data management. Mobility, once a voice-centric domain, now encompasses mobile internet, and this reality - is impacting device demand trends in computing and communications. Information Processing - AI is driving growth in computing, both in GPU-based servers and in on-device Gen AI for PCs and smartphones. It also is disrupting the data center, as cloud service providers accelerate growth with the help of leading computing and semiconductor companies. . - Overall semiconductor demand, formerly driven first by PCs and then by the proliferation of mobile devices, now has multiple secular drivers. These include AI data center, legacy cloud data center, Internet of Things (IoT) & factory automation, EV & hybrid EV, autonomous vehicles, robotics, and more. - The need for massive GPU clusters to train Large Language Models (LLMs) and for inferencing for generative AI has led to explosive demand for GPU computing implementations and has become as one of the most significant semiconductor drivers. - ARM-based cores (licensed from ARM Holdings Ltd.) that power smartphones and tablet PCs have disrupted the hegemony in processing once enjoyed by x86 architecture. Traditional x86 processor companies such as Intel and AMD are fighting back with lower-power products that integrate central processing and graphics processing within a single die. - The nature of memory is changing, with mobile computers transitioning away from hard disk drive-based memory (HDD) to solid-state memory (SSD). Memory demand too is accelerating as data storage accommodates massive AI-related traffic flows. - New software-centric developments such as collaboration, virtualization, cloud computing, SaaS, analytics, and interactivity are transferring the software power center onto public and private cloud networks serving enterprises. At the same time, advances in mobility and competitive developments have driven demand for mobile devices and, in turn, mobile applications supplied by nontraditional players. - These factors have diminished the central role once played by Microsoft's operating system and applications. At the same time, enterprise software companies have prioritized enabling AI for their customers, leading to strong growth for major industry participants including Salesforce Inc, ServiceNow, Oracle, and more. © 2025 Argus Research Company ARGUS A6 Report logo: ARGUS RESEARCH • The image is a logo for "ARGUS RESEARCH". • The logo consists of a stylized white archway or capital "A" inside a blue circle, with a small globe at the base of the arch. • To the right of the icon, the word "ARGUS" appears in large, uppercase serif font, with a registered trademark symbol (®) at the upper right. • Below "ARGUS", the word "RESEARCH" is written in smaller, spaced-out uppercase letters. • The background is a solid blue rectangle. • The overall dimensions are horizontal, with the icon on the left and text on the right. Analysis : • The use of blue and white conveys a professional, trustworthy image, suitable for a research or financial analysis firm. • The globe and archway may symbolize global reach and stability. Argus A6 Quantitative Universe Our A6 Quantitative Universe includes more than 1,500 companies that are diversified across all asset classes and industry sectors. Ratings for these companies are derived through a proprietary algorithm we have designed and tested so that the ratings are based on our fundamental Six-Point System. Our A6 Quantitative Ratings include sub-ratings for each of the six factors. The A6 algorithm is designed to capture and analyze financial trends for each company under coverage. Companies are measured against their historical record, peer group, and the broad market. For each covered company, the A6 algorithm generates a subrating for growth, financial strength, industry outlook, management, risk/safety and valuation. These scores are totaled and provide an overall rating for each company. The A6 algorithm rates stocks on growth based on normalized earnings estimates and sales trends, among other factors. Our financial strength ranking is based primarily on balance sheet debt and liquidity ratios. For risk, we factor in liquidity, dividend yield, market cap, debt leverage and stock price beta. Our valuation subrating includes factors such as price/earnings and price/sales ratios, trend lines, and discounted cash flow valuations. Ratings are reviewed weekly. Summary : This bar chart shows the distribution of analyst ratings (Buy, Sell, Hold) across different stock market sectors. bar chart: Title & Axes : • Title: "RATING DISTRIBUTION SECTOR". • Y-axis: Sectors (Communication Services, Consumer Discretionary, Consumer Staples, Energy, Financial, Healthcare, Industrial, Information Technology, Materials, Real Estate, Utilities). • X-axis: Number of ratings (tick marks at 0, 50, 100, 150, 200, 250, 300). Data Points : • For each sector, three bars represent the number of Buy (green), Sell (red), and Hold (yellow) ratings. • Communication Services: Buy ≈ 10, Sell ≈ 10, Hold ≈ 90. • Consumer Discretionary: Buy ≈ 30, Sell ≈ 20, Hold ≈ 120. • Consumer Staples: Buy ≈ 30, Sell ≈ 10, Hold ≈ 80. • Energy: Buy ≈ 40, Sell ≈ 10, Hold ≈ 70. • Financial: Buy ≈ 60, Sell ≈ 20, Hold ≈ 180. • Healthcare: Buy ≈ 60, Sell ≈ 20, Hold ≈ 180. • Industrial: Buy ≈ 60, Sell ≈ 20, Hold ≈ 250. • Information Technology: Buy ≈ 60, Sell ≈ 20, Hold ≈ 180. • Materials: Buy ≈ 30, Sell ≈ 10, Hold ≈ 80. • Real Estate: Buy ≈ 10, Sell ≈ 10, Hold ≈ 60. • Utilities: Buy ≈ 10, Sell ≈ 10, Hold ≈ 40. Design Encodings : • Buy ratings: green bars. • Sell ratings: red bars. • Hold ratings: yellow bars. • Horizontal stacked bar format for each sector. • Legend at the bottom: green = Buy, red = Sell, yellow = Hold. Distribution & Trends : • Hold ratings (yellow) are the most numerous in every sector. • Buy and Sell ratings are much fewer than Hold ratings across all sectors. • Industrial sector has the highest number of Hold ratings (≈ 250). • Utilities and Real Estate have the lowest total ratings. Analysis : • Across all sectors, analysts overwhelmingly issue Hold ratings compared to Buy or Sell. • The Industrial, Financial, Healthcare, and Information Technology sectors have the highest total number of ratings, especially Holds. • Sectors like Utilities and Real Estate have the fewest ratings overall. • There is a consistent pattern of more Buy than Sell ratings, but both are much less frequent than Hold ratings in every sector. Summary : This figure presents the distribution of market capitalisation (market cap) across three different stock universes—All Stocks, Argus Fundamental Universe, and Argus A6 (Quant) Universe—using pie charts to show the proportions of Large Cap, Mid Cap, and Small Cap stocks. pie charts: # Title & Layout : • Main title: "MARKET CAP DISTRIBUTION". • Three pie charts: "ALL STOCKS" (top left), "ARGUS FUNDAMENTAL UNIVERSE" (bottom left), "ARGUS A6 (QUANT) UNIVERSE" (bottom right). • Legend at top right: Large Cap (purple), Mid Cap (yellow), Small Cap (green). # Data Points : • ALL STOCKS: – Large Cap: 45.8% – Mid Cap: 34.3% – Small Cap: 19.8% • ARGUS FUNDAMENTAL UNIVERSE: – Large Cap: 86.4% – Mid Cap: 10.5% – Small Cap: 3% • ARGUS A6 (QUANT) UNIVERSE: – Large Cap: 44.9% – Mid Cap: 27.8% – Small Cap: 27.3% # Design Encodings : • Colour coding: Large Cap (purple), Mid Cap (yellow), Small Cap (green). • Each pie chart is divided into three segments corresponding to the cap sizes. • Percentages are labelled directly on each segment. # Analysis : • The Argus Fundamental Universe is heavily weighted towards Large Cap stocks (86.4%), with very small representation of Small Cap (3%). • The All Stocks and Argus A6 (Quant) Universes have a more balanced distribution, with Large Cap stocks comprising about 45%, and Small and Mid Cap stocks making up the remainder in roughly equal or slightly varying proportions. • The Argus A6 (Quant) Universe has a notably higher proportion of Small Cap stocks (27.3%) compared to the Argus Fundamental Universe. • The data highlights significant differences in market cap composition between the universes, especially the dominance of Large Caps in the Fundamental Universe. Summary : This bar chart shows the current distribution of analyst ratings among three categories: Buy, Sell, and Hold, with corresponding percentages and approximate counts. bar chart: Title & Axes : • Title: "CURRENT RATING DISTRIBUTION". • X-axis: Rating categories ("Buy", "Sell", "Hold"). • Y-axis: Count (range: 0 to 1000, tick marks at 0, 200, 400, 600, 800, 1000).   • Below "ARGUS", the word "RESEARCH" appears in smaller, spaced-out uppercase letters.
  • The background is solid blue, and all text and the archway are white.

Dimensions and Placement :

  • The logo is horizontally oriented, with the icon and text aligned on a single line.

Analysis :
  • The use of a globe and archway suggests a global or comprehensive perspective, fitting for a research or analytics firm.
  • The blue and white color scheme conveys professionalism and trust.

ADVANCED MICRO DEVICES
(NAS:AMD)
Report Date: July 09, 2025

Summary : This figure shows a time series line chart of a variable fluctuating between approximately $55 and $214, spanning from early 2023 to mid-2025.

line chart:
Title & Axes :
  • No explicit title visible.
  • X-axis: Date, labeled with major ticks at Jan 1 and Jul 1 for years 2023, 2024, and 2025.
  • Y-axis: Value in dollars ($), with tick labels at $55, $87, $119, $150, $182, and $214.

Data Points :
  • Single series plotted as a continuous blue line.
  • Data points are not individually marked; the line is smooth and continuous.
  • The series starts near $70 in early 2023, dips below $60, rises steadily through 2023, peaks above $200 in early 2024, then fluctuates and trends downward, with a recovery in mid-2025.

Design Encodings :
  • Blue line, no markers, no gridlines, no error bars or confidence intervals.
  • No log scale or dual axes.

Distribution & Trends :
  • Initial decline from early 2023 to mid-2023.
  • Gradual increase from mid-2023, accelerating into early 2024.
  • Sharp peak above $200 in early 2024.
  • Volatile fluctuations through 2024, with several local peaks and troughs.
  • Downward trend into early 2025, followed by a recovery toward mid-2025.

Analysis :
  • The data shows a pronounced rise from mid-2023 to early 2024, reaching a maximum above $200.
  • After the peak, the series becomes volatile, with multiple ups and downs.
  • There is a notable decline in early 2025, but the value recovers by mid-2025.
  • The overall pattern is cyclical with a major peak in early 2024 and a recovery phase in mid-2025.

Over the past year, AMD shares are down 25.1%, versus a gain of 10.5% for the broader market. The 52 week trading range is $76.48 to $187.28. The Argus A6 target price is $145 representing a 5.2% gain from the current level.
Advanced Micro Devices designs a variety of digital semiconductors for markets such as PCs, gaming consoles, data centers, industrial, and automotive applications.

Our rating on the Information Technology sector is Over-Weight. Consumer electronics demand, which was reduced by inflation, is now showing signs of recovery. IT demand in enterprise and data center markets weakened after consumer demand but now also shows signs of recovery, fueled by mounting interest in generative AI.

As of the end of May, the sector accounted for 31.6% of the S&P 500. Over the past
five years, the weighting has ranged from 16% to 33%. The sector was
underperforming the market, with a loss of 1.8%. The sector outperformed in 2024,
with a gain of 35.7% compared to a gain of 23.3% for the S&P 500.

The sector's P/E ratio on projected 2026 EPS was 23, above the market multiple. Yields of 0.2% were below the market average. The sector's smoothed earnings growth rate of 15% was above the market average.

Over the long term, we expect the Tech sector to benefit from pervasive digitization across the economy, greater acceptance of transformative technologies, and the development of the Internet of Things (IoT). Generative AI is poised to become a huge industry driver, although timeline of actual AI deployments is uncertain. Healthy company and sector fundamentals are also positive. For individual companies, these include high cash levels, low debt, and broad international business exposure.

Key Sector Trends

Communications Equipment

- Data demand is exploding because of mobile internet, video on the web, social networking and other factors. Generative AI has shifted from an emerging driver to perhaps the most-significant factor in communications equipment demand. AI is driving demand for bandwidth capacity at the optical transport level as well as network efficiency (IP) and ubiquity (Ethernet) at the access level.
- Prevailing trends in the global information society - including collaboration, virtualization, cloud, social networking, and exponential growth in "big" file-based data - are driving the need for more network "intelligence," meaning security, efficiency, extensibility, personalization, and sophisticated data management. Mobility, once a voice-centric domain, now encompasses mobile internet, and this reality

- is impacting device demand trends in computing and communications.

Information Processing

- AI is driving growth in computing, both in GPU-based servers and in on-device Gen AI for PCs and smartphones. It also is disrupting the data center, as cloud service providers accelerate growth with the help of leading computing and semiconductor companies. .

- Overall semiconductor demand, formerly driven first by PCs and then by the proliferation of mobile devices, now has multiple secular drivers. These include AI data center, legacy cloud data center, Internet of Things (IoT) & factory automation, EV & hybrid EV, autonomous vehicles, robotics, and more.
- The need for massive GPU clusters to train Large Language Models (LLMs) and for inferencing for generative AI has led to explosive demand for GPU computing implementations and has become as one of the most significant semiconductor drivers.
- ARM-based cores (licensed from ARM Holdings Ltd.) that power smartphones and tablet PCs have disrupted the hegemony in processing once enjoyed by x86 architecture. Traditional x86 processor companies such as Intel and AMD are fighting back with lower-power products that integrate central processing and graphics processing within a single die.
- The nature of memory is changing, with mobile computers transitioning away from hard disk drive-based memory (HDD) to solid-state memory (SSD). Memory demand too is accelerating as data storage accommodates massive AI-related traffic flows.

- New software-centric developments such as collaboration, virtualization, cloud computing, SaaS, analytics, and interactivity are transferring the software power center onto public and private cloud networks serving enterprises. At the same time, advances in mobility and competitive developments have driven demand for mobile devices and, in turn, mobile applications supplied by nontraditional players.
- These factors have diminished the central role once played by Microsoft's operating system and applications. At the same time, enterprise software companies have prioritized enabling AI for their customers, leading to strong growth for major industry participants including Salesforce Inc, ServiceNow, Oracle, and more.

logo: ARGUS RESEARCH

  • The image is a logo for "ARGUS RESEARCH".
  • The logo consists of a stylized white archway or capital "A" inside a blue circle, with a small globe at the base of the arch.
  • To the right of the icon, the word "ARGUS" appears in large, uppercase serif font, with a registered trademark symbol (®) at the upper right.
  • Below "ARGUS", the word "RESEARCH" is written in smaller, spaced-out uppercase letters.
  • The background is a solid blue rectangle.
  • The overall dimensions are horizontal, with the icon on the left and text on the right.

Analysis : 
  • The use of blue and white conveys a professional, trustworthy image, suitable for a research or financial analysis firm.
  • The globe and archway may symbolize global reach and stability.

Argus A6 Quantitative Universe

Our A6 Quantitative Universe includes more than 1,500 companies that are diversified across all asset classes and industry sectors. Ratings for these companies are derived through a proprietary algorithm we have designed and tested so that the ratings are based on our fundamental Six-Point System. Our A6 Quantitative Ratings include sub-ratings for each of the six factors.

The A6 algorithm is designed to capture and analyze financial trends for each company under coverage. Companies are measured against their historical record, peer group, and the broad market. For each covered company, the A6 algorithm generates a subrating for growth, financial strength, industry outlook, management, risk/safety and valuation. These scores are totaled and provide an overall rating for each company. The A6 algorithm rates stocks on growth based on normalized earnings estimates and sales trends, among other factors. Our financial strength ranking is based primarily on balance sheet debt and liquidity ratios. For risk, we factor in liquidity, dividend yield, market cap, debt leverage and stock price beta. Our valuation subrating includes factors such as price/earnings and price/sales ratios, trend lines, and discounted cash flow valuations. Ratings are reviewed weekly.

Argus Research Disclaimer

In addition, this content is not prepared subject to Canadian disclosure requirements. This report is not an offer to sell or a solicitation of an offer to buy any security. The information and material presented in this report are for general information only and do not specifically address individual investment objectives, financial situations or the particular needs of any specific person who may receive this report. Investing in any security or investment strategies discussed may not be suitable for you and it is recommended that you consult an independent investment advisor. Argus is under no obligation to ensure that other reports are brought to the attention of any recipient of this report. Summary : This bar chart shows the distribution of analyst ratings (Buy, Sell, Hold) across different stock market sectors.

bar chart:
Title & Axes :
  • Title: "RATING DISTRIBUTION SECTOR".
  • Y-axis: Sectors (Communication Services, Consumer Discretionary, Consumer Staples, Energy, Financial, Healthcare, Industrial, Information Technology, Materials, Real Estate, Utilities).
  • X-axis: Number of ratings (tick marks at 0, 50, 100, 150, 200, 250, 300).

Data Points :
  • For each sector, three bars represent the number of Buy (green), Sell (red), and Hold (yellow) ratings.
  • Communication Services: Buy ≈ 10, Sell ≈ 10, Hold ≈ 90.
  • Consumer Discretionary: Buy ≈ 30, Sell ≈ 20, Hold ≈ 120.
  • Consumer Staples: Buy ≈ 30, Sell ≈ 10, Hold ≈ 80.
  • Energy: Buy ≈ 40, Sell ≈ 10, Hold ≈ 70.
  • Financial: Buy ≈ 60, Sell ≈ 20, Hold ≈ 180.
  • Healthcare: Buy ≈ 60, Sell ≈ 20, Hold ≈ 180.
  • Industrial: Buy ≈ 60, Sell ≈ 20, Hold ≈ 250.
  • Information Technology: Buy ≈ 60, Sell ≈ 20, Hold ≈ 180.
  • Materials: Buy ≈ 30, Sell ≈ 10, Hold ≈ 80.
  • Real Estate: Buy ≈ 10, Sell ≈ 10, Hold ≈ 60.
  • Utilities: Buy ≈ 10, Sell ≈ 10, Hold ≈ 40.

Design Encodings :
  • Buy ratings: green bars.
  • Sell ratings: red bars.
  • Hold ratings: yellow bars.
  • Horizontal stacked bar format for each sector.
  • Legend at the bottom: green = Buy, red = Sell, yellow = Hold.

Distribution & Trends :
  • Hold ratings (yellow) are the most numerous in every sector.
  • Buy and Sell ratings are much fewer than Hold ratings across all sectors.
  • Industrial sector has the highest number of Hold ratings (≈ 250).
  • Utilities and Real Estate have the lowest total ratings.

Analysis :
  • Across all sectors, analysts overwhelmingly issue Hold ratings compared to Buy or Sell.
  • The Industrial, Financial, Healthcare, and Information Technology sectors have the highest total number of ratings, especially Holds.
  • Sectors like Utilities and Real Estate have the fewest ratings overall.
  • There is a consistent pattern of more Buy than Sell ratings, but both are much less frequent than Hold ratings in every sector.

Summary : This figure presents the distribution of market capitalisation (market cap) across three different stock universes—All Stocks, Argus Fundamental Universe, and Argus A6 (Quant) Universe—using pie charts to show the proportions of Large Cap, Mid Cap, and Small Cap stocks.
